explanation: For each symbol:  - MHD_queue_response: called by ahc_echo; inspect its body for any for-statements that could rely on or be affected by objects in ahc_echo.  - MHD_create_response_from_buffer_copy / MHD_create_response_from_buffer / MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback / MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static / MHD_create_response_from_callback / MHD_create_response_from_fd64 / MHD_create_response_empty / MHD_create_response_for_upgrade / MHD_add_response_header / MHD_lookup_connection_value / MHD_digest_auth_check3 / MHD_queue_auth_required_response3 / MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3 / MHD_queue_basic_auth_required_response3 / MHD_free / can_compress / body_compress: all are direct callees (from the static call graph). Each must be available so the analyzer can check whether any for-loops they contain are well-formed and whether those loops use or modify objects that are also accessed or modified by ahc_echo (MISRA explicitly counts the behaviour of functions called within a for-statement as part of the loop body).  - malloc / free: ahc_echo calls malloc; any implementation or wrappers that contain for-loops should be checked. Also free is included because MHD_free or other response creation helpers may call it.  - strlen / printf / strerror: standard-library calls used in ahc_echo; their implementations may contain loops (e.g. strlen). The analyzer should at least know these symbols to decide whether their internal loops interact with ahc_echo’s objects (usually they do not).  - timerfd_create / timerfd_settime / epoll_ctl: system calls used to create and arm timers and epoll; include to inspect whether they wrap loops or modify shared objects used in potential loops.  - evt (struct epoll_event) and epfd (int): globals used by ahc_echo when calling epoll_ctl; their definitions are needed to ensure they are not also loop counters or objects used as loop flags elsewhere.  - errno / CLOCK_MONOTONIC / TFD_NONBLOCK / EPOLLIN: constants/globals used by the function; include to ensure they are not aliases to objects that could be used as loop counters or flags.  - struct Request: definition (fields connection and timerfd) is required to know what objects ahc_echo modifies; MISRA forbids a loop counter being modified in the loop body — the analyzer must know which objects ahc_echo writes to.  - struct itimerspec: definition (it_value/it_interval members) is used and must be known to check whether these objects are used as loop counters or flags.  - struct MHD_Connection / struct MHD_Response: types passed to and returned from called functions; their internal fields might be used as loop counters/flags inside callees.  - enum MHD_Result and constants MHD_YES / MHD_NO / MHD_HTTP_OK: return/result values used by ahc_echo; include so an analyzer can follow control flow and determine whether loops in callees are executed in contexts relevant to MISRA checks.  - size_t: type of upload_data_size and sizes used with strlen; include for completeness.  Rationale summary: MISRA's for-loop rule requires auditing all for-statements in the function and in functions called within any for-statement's body, and also requires checking whether loop counters/flags are modified elsewhere. To determine compliance for ahc_echo you must therefore have the callees’ definitions (to find any for-loops and their counters/flags) and all global/type definitions and objects that ahc_echo reads or writes (so you can determine whether any for-loop counter/flag in callees could be the same object or be modified by ahc_echo). The symbols above are the minimal close set needed to perform that analysis.
